text: So, I want us to run through the forms of ABER, this TO HAVE that we use to go into the past.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that we can remember them by looking at the two vowel sounds that we have inside the word ABER.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So give me I HAVE and WE HAVE. E and EMOS.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And give me the rest of the versions.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that nouns ending A are feminine nouns.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, for example, THE HOUSE, LA CASA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, words ending A are feminine, but words ending MA are masculine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There's a small group of words that end MA which are masculine words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: For example, THE PROBLEM in Spanish is EL PROBLEMA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, HAVE YOU UNDERSTOOD THE PROBLEM?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We can use COMPRENDER or we can use ENTENDER, but COMPRENDER is perfect here as well.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And let's talk formally, TO USTED.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, a very common error for people learning Spanish is to say LA PROBLEMA.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if we look at why these words ending MA are actually masculine, it's going to help us internalise it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, these words that end MA actually come from Greek.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say THE SYSTEM?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, in Greek, these words are neuter words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: In Greek, you have masculine, feminine and neuter.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And neuter words in Greek look like masculine words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They have a similar word for THE.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: They look kind of like masculine words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, when they went IN to Spanish or IN to Latin, they got mistaken as masculine words.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if we can identify them, there's a key group of words we can avoid committing this error with.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: If it ends MA, it's probably from Greek and probably masculine.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say THE SYSTEM again?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, HAVE YOU UNDERSTOOD THE SYSTEM?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And you can also use it like TO PERCEIVE in the sense of SMELL.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, if you wanted to ask, for example, HAVE YOU FELT THE AROMA?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: It would be a way of asking, HAVE YOU SMELLED THE AROMA?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: EL PROBLEMA, EL SISTEMA, EL PROGRAMA, EL AROMA, EL PANORAMA, EL CLIMA, which is a little bit different in English, which means CLIMATE, EL CLIMA, and some others.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, I HAVE LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, what if you wanted to emphasize, I HAVE LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, if you want to say, I HAVE GOT LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: I'VE GOT LOST. You can just say, I'VE LOST MYSELF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said, I GET READY as I PREPARE MYSELF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We don't use this in Spanish, I GET READY.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, you don't say, I GET LOST or I HAVE GOT LOST. You say, I HAVE LOST MYSELF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say that?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: When you say it fluently, it doesn't actually sound any different.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Which is why I asked for it again, to make sure that you are putting it.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Because the E of ME and the E of E will blend together.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, that means, I HAVE LOST MYSELF or I'VE GOT LOST. Now, what if you wanted to be emphatic as well and say, I HAVE LOST MYSELF?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: We said that the word for YOU, in the sense of YOU LOSE, YOU SEE, not I SEE YOU, but YOU SEE, is TU for informal YOU.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, YOU HAVE LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: There's a bit of a contradiction there.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, just as ME can mean ME or MYSELF, TE can mean YOU or YOURSELF.
speaker: Speaker 1

text: So, how would you say, YOU HAVE GOT LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what if you wanted to be emphatic as well?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: What was WE HAVE from HABER?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: How would you say, WE HAVE LOST IT?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: Now, how would you say, WE HAVE LOST OURSELVES or WE'VE GOT LOST?
speaker: Speaker 1

text: And what if you wanted to say, WE HAVE GOT LOST. WE HAVE LOST OURSELVES.
speaker: Speaker 1
